page.title: 03Chatteris - Pumping Stations
page.content: When Vermuyden drained the area, the peat shrank and we found that the land would not drain naturally, so the Dutch brought their windmills and people to look after them. These windmills were replaced by steam pumps. Nowadays, the drainage men told us, nearly all pumps are electric. This area has two drainage districts, Nightlayer's and Normoor. All the little drains that criss cross the farmland carry water to the Forty Foot drain, and the water is pumped by an electric pump. No one looks after this pump and the farmers have to pay Nightlayer's drainage district for this. The Normoor pumping station on the Sixteen Foot Bank is no longer working. The farmer said that the old engine worked by disel and if the pumps were switched off we would all be underwater very soon.
